techniques.name: Network Service Discovery
techniques.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of services running on remote hosts, including those that may be vulnerable to remote software exploitation.

techniques.name: Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over a different protocol than that of the existing command and control channel.

techniques.name: Application Layer Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may use an existing, legitimate external Web service as a means for sending commands to and receiving output from a compromised system over the Web service channel.

techniques.name: Proxy
techniques.description: Adversaries may use a connection proxy to direct network traffic between systems or act as an intermediary for network communications to a command and control server.

techniques.name: Non-Application Layer Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may use a non-application layer protocol for communication between host and C2 server or among infected hosts within a network.

techniques.name: Exploit Public-Facing Application
techniques.description: Adversaries may exploit a vulnerability in an Internet-facing computer or program using software, data, or commands in order to cause unintended or unanticipated behavior.

techniques.name: Non-Standard Port
techniques.description: Adversaries may communicate using a protocol and port pairing that is typically not associated with the protocol.

techniques.name: Brute Force
techniques.description: Adversaries may use brute force techniques to gain access to accounts when passwords are unknown or when password hashes are obtained.

techniques.name: Remote Services
techniques.description: Adversaries may use valid accounts to log into a service remotely that accepts remote connections.

techniques.name: Remote Services: SSH
techniques.description: Adversaries may use SSH to move laterally within an environment.

techniques.name: Remote Services: Remote Desktop Protocol
techniques.description: Adversaries may use valid accounts to log into a computer using the Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP).

techniques.name: Remote Services: SMB/Windows Admin Shares
techniques.description: Adversaries may use valid accounts to interact with remote network shares using Server Message Block (SMB).

techniques.name: Command and Scripting Interpreter
techniques.description: Adversaries may abuse command and script interpreters to execute commands, scripts, or binaries.

tactics.name: Initial Access
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to get into your network.

tactics.name: Execution
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to run malicious code.

tactics.name: Persistence
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to maintain their foothold.

tactics.name: Privilege Escalation
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to gain higher-level permissions.

tactics.name: Defense Evasion
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to avoid being detected.

tactics.name: Credential Access
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to steal account names and passwords.

tactics.name: Discovery
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to figure out your environment.

tactics.name: Lateral Movement
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to move through your environment.

tactics.name: Collection
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to gather data of interest.

tactics.name: Exfiltration
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to steal data.

tactics.name: Command and Control
tactics.description: The adversary is trying to communicate with compromised systems to control them.
